turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Your door was unlocked.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Still is, so let yourself out.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: We need to talk.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: We ain't got nothing to talk about.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: I messed up, okay, I know that.  But I ain't that kid's father.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Lucky kid.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Look, I ain't saying it was right, but sometimes things happen.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: And some things should never fucking happen!

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Boy, you're so perfect you can look down on me?

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: I ain't a damn liar.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Your mom was real quick to show you those pictures, wasn't she? Well, she was nineteen when she got pregnant and don't get me wrong, you're the best thing in my life, but she knew I wasn't ready for no marriage.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: So now you're saying my mother trapped you?

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: I'm saying I handled my responsibilities like a man.  But when you're in the NBA, you pull into a city and there's a hundred women waiting at the hotel.  And another twenty that made it past security on your floor.  And the boldest one is standing right at your door.  And after awhile, it just becomes part of the game.  I'm sorry I lied to you, I shouldn't have.  But I did it cause I love you.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Since we're being honest, guess I should tell you.  I'm dropping out of school and going pro.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: From your mouth.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: I know your mad at me, okay, but I can't let you do this.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Always thought "can't" wasn't in a man's vocabulary.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Came by to check on you.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: After five years.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Don't remember that being my fault. Seems like you divorced me same time as your mom.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Look, I'm busy.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: I can see that.  I know things look pretty bleak right now, but you can't get down on yourself.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: I stopped taking your advice a long time ago, or did you forget?

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Quincy.  I know you left school early to throw your middle finger up at me.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: And now I'm paying for it, right?  That what this is about?  "I told you so?"

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: You want me to fuck off?

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Fine, I'll fuck off, but not til I say something.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: What surery?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Oral surgery.  Corrective teeth surgery.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: Your teeth are straight.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I need corrective oral surgery. I need the braces.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: Don, you got hit by lightning that time in Tahoe, you went on vacation, I don't think braces is a good idea --

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I can't believe you're gonna do this to me, the situation I'm in, I don't -- Avi: You know what?  Being hit by lighting doesn't matter for getting braces, ok? Now Solomon, let me just ask you once: Please. Please. Don't do this.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: How are you paying tor the braces, Donnie?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: No need for braces, Donnie.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: THAT'S NONE OF YOUR BUSSINESS. I HAVE BEEN A GOOD WORKER, A GOOD AND LOYAL WORKER FOR YOU, YOU FUCKING ASSHOLE.

turns.speaker: AVI
turns.text: HEY FUCK YOU DON WATCH IT NOW.

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: You smell like trouble --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'm fuckin' hammered, Burt.

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: You ok?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: ooohhhhhh no.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: It's been the same fuckin' thing for thirty years, Burt --

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: These adults are tough enough, I think you'll be surprised -- the Mexican's a bit of a question mark --

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: You okay?  huh?  Jimmy?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: And the book says: "We may by through with the past, but the past ain't through with us."

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: C'mon, Jimmy, snap up, snap up --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: In my sleep, Burt.

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: Call 911. Call 911 right now.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: No, no, no. I'm fine. It's small, I wanna keep going --

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: no, no, c'mon Jimmy we need to call this quits and you need to see a doctor.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'm telling you right now, I'm fine. I lost my goddamn balance and I couldn't see a moment, but I'm ok.

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: Call 911, Mary, do it right now.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: You fuckin' don't do that. You don't do it, you cocksucker. I'll fuckin' kill you with my barehands.  Go. get the fuck fuck -- we're going back and we finish the show --

turns.speaker: BURT
turns.text: Jimmy you look like you're about to fuckin' die right here --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Shut it.  Shut yer fuckin' mouth.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Hey, Janet, it's Chad.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Nothing's wrong, I just got some guy on the phone on my other line, he's says he works for this guy, this guy who's Frank's father --

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: -- no,no,no what is this? who? What's this guy's name?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Ok. Janet you have Phil Parma --

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Hello, Phil.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Hi, hello, great.  This is Seduce and Destroy?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: It is.  Can I have your home phone number with area code?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Well I don't want to order anything, you see. I have a situation, a situation just come up that's really pretty serious and I'm not sure who I should talk to or what I should do but could you maybe put me in touch with the right person if I explain myself?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: I'm really only equipped to take orders --

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Well can you connect me to someone else?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Well what's the situation?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Well, ok.  Lemme see how I explain this without it seeming kinda crazy, but here go:  I'm, my name is Phil Parma and I work for a man named Earl Partridge -- Mr. Earl Partidge. I'm his nurse.  He's a very sick man. He's a dying man and he's sick and he's asked me to help him, to help him find his son -- Hello?  Are you there, hello?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: I'm here, I'm listening.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: OK.  See:  Frank TJ Macky is Earl Partridge's son....

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Why don't they have the same last name? They don't have the same last name.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I know -- and I can't really explain that, but I have a feeling there's something, some situation between them, like they don't really know each other much or well, something like they don't talk much anymore --

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Does this sound weird?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Well I'm not sure why you're calling me.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: There's no number for Frank in any of Earl's stuff and he's pretty out of it -- I mean, like I said, he's dying, y'know.  Dying of Cancer.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: What kind of Cancer?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Brain and Lung.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: My mother had breast cancer.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It's rough.  I'm sorry, did she make it?

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Oh, she's fine.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh that's good.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: It was scary though.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It's a helluva disease.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Sure is.  So why call me?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yeah, hey. Chad.

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Alright, so I'm gonna transfer you over to Frank's assitant, Janet she's gonna see what she can do --

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Thank you, Chad, and good luck to you and your mother --

turns.speaker: CHAD
turns.text: Thank you.  Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: ...what the fuck is this...?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: It's me.  Claudia.  It's me.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What do you want? Why are you here?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'd like to talk to you.  Your boyfriend let me in, I just knocked on the door --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: He's not my boyfriend.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Wanna call me a slut now, something?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: No.  No.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What the fuck do you want?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I want to sit.  I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Don't sit down.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: ...I want to....I want so many things, Claudia. Maybe we can just talk to straighten our things out....there are so many things that I want to tell you --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I don't wanna talk to you.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Please.  It doesn't have to be now. Maybe we can make a date to sit down, I didn't mean to walk in on you like this --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Why are you here, why are you doing this? Coming in here -- you wanna call me a whore?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I don't want you to think that I'm that way to you -- I'm not gonna call you a slut or something --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah, yeah right -- what the fuck are doing?  WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING IN MY HOUSE?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Don't yell, honey.  Please don't go crazy --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'M NOT CRAZY.  Don't you tell me I'm crazy.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'm not saying that, I'm sorry --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'M NOT CRAZY.  You're the one.  You're the one who's wrong.  You're the one --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I have something, so much -- I'm sick, Claudia. I'm sick.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Get out of here, get the fuck out of my house --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Now STOP IT and LISTEN to me right now. I AM DYING, I GOT SICK...now I fell down and I'm Not...DON'T --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: GET THE FUCK OUT.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'm dying, Claudia.  I have cancer. I have cancer and I'm dying, soon. It's metastasized in my bones and I --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: FUCK YOU.  FUCK YOU, YOU GET OUT.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I'm not lying to you, I'm not --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: FUCK YOU.  YOU GET THE FUCK OUT OF HERE.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: baby, please, please --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'M NOT YOUR BABY, I'M NOT YOUR GIRL. I'm not your fuckin' baby --

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Please put your clothes on, please --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: YOU BURN IN BELL.  You burn in hell and you deserve it -- YOU GET THE FUCK OUT.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Honey.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: GET OUT.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Your mother wants to hear from you --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: GET THE FUCK OUT OF HERE.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: ...Hello...?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: LAPD. Open the door.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: uh...uh...What is it?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: It's the LAPD, can you open the door, please?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: OPEN THE DOOR.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm coming!

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: ...yeah...

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry, I had to get dressed.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No one else in there with you?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Ok. For one thing, we're gonna need to turn that music down so we can talk, ok?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Wilson.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Ok.  Claudia Wilson: You tryin' to go deaf?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Did you hear what I said?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah, but I don't know --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- listenin' to that music so loud: You Tryin' To Damage Your Ears?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Well if you keep listenin' to the music that loud you're not only gonna damage your ears but your neighbors ears.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I didn't realize it was that loud.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: And that could be the sign of a damaged ear drum, you understand?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You got the TV on too, keep those on at that same time usually?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I got a call of a disturbance, screaming and yelling, loud music.  Has there been some screaming and yelling?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yes.  I had someone come to my door, someone I didn't want here and I told them to leave -- so -- it's no big deal. They left.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Was it a boyfriend of yours?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You don't have a boyfriend?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Who was it?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I was...he's gone...I mean it's not. It's over, y'know --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You mind if I check things back here?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: It's fine.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What are you lookin' for?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Claudia: Why don't you let me handle the questions and you handle the answers, ok?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: ok.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You just move in here?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: About two years ago.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Bit messy.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I'm a bit of a slob myself.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You and your boyfriend have a party last night?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I don't have a boyfriend.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: got some coffee brewing, huh?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah...it's not...it's been on for a bit --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I like iced coffee, generally, but a day like this, rain and what not, I enjoy a warm cup --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: -- do you wanna cup?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: That's great, thank you.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I don't know how fresh it's gonna be --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Oh, it'll be fine, I'm sure, Claudia.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You take cream or sugar?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: That'd be fine.  So, Claudia, lemme just say, so I can get my role of LAPD officer out of the way before we enjoy our coffee  I'm not gonna write you up or anything, I'm not gonna give you a citation here -- but the real problem we have is that there are people around here, people that work from their homes, people tryin' to get some work done, and if you're listenin' to your music that loud:  They're incovenienced by that.  If you had a job you'd probably understand, but I see you like listenin' to your music and that's fine, you're just gonna wanna keep it down at a certain volume, maybe memorize what number you see on the dial and just always put it to that -- If it's the middle of the day -- that's what I do -- just put it on two and a half and that's a good listening level, alright? I see you like listenin' to your music loud, but, hey, forget about the neighbors, you end up damaging your own ears ok?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Arlight, then.  Cheers.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Is this boyfriend bothering you?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I don't have a boyfriend.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: The gentleman who came to the door --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: -- is not my boyfriend.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Many times, in damestic abuse situations the young lady is afraid to speak, but I have to tell you that, being a police officer, I've seen it happen: Young woman afraid to speak, next thing you know, I'm gettin' a call on the radio, I got a 422 --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: It's not -- what's a 422?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: It's where situations like these lead, Claudia, unless you do something about it early, if and when the police call and come for help.  Now there are certain measures you can take --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: It's not my boyfriend -- and it's not anything -- it's over.  Really. It's not.  He won't came back.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I don't wanna have to come back here in an hour and find that there's been another disturbance.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You won't.  You won't have to.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: But I wouldn't mind comin' back in an hour just to see your pretty face!

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm gonna run to the bathroom real quick.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Okey-doke.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Ok, ok. I'm back.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: This is, for not a fresh cup, a great cup of coffee, Claudia --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: --- yeah, yeah, I get in it in my ear. It's TMJ is what it's called technically.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: What's that stand for?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Tempural-something-mandibular, thing with something, I dunno. But it affects my ear, I don't even know if I have TMJ exactly but just very tight, like - it's like a muscle spasm and it's just gets so clenched --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: This is my job.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: We were just gettin' warmed up. We were just getting started.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Well if you listen' to that music too loud again and that fella returns maybe we'll share another cup of coffee --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: If you're not here for a 422 --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No. No.  Don't joke about that. That's not funny, Claudia.  Please, now.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Ok, then.  Keep your chin up and your music down, alright?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Yes.  I will.  It was nice to meet you Officer Jim.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Just Jim.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: yeah, good, ok.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Bye, bye, Claudia.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Good bye.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I'm sorry, Claudia.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What is it?  Did you forget something?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No, no.  I was wondering...man oh man. I think I feel like a bit of a scum-bucket doing this, considering that I came here as an officer of the law and the situation and all this but I think I'd be a fool if I didn't do something I really want to do which is to ask you on a date.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You wanna go on a date with me?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Please, yes.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Well...is that illegal?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Then...I'd like to go...What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I don't know.  I haven't thought about it -- you know what -- that's not true -- I have thought about it.  I've thought about going on a date with you since you opened the door.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I thought you were flirting with me a little.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Do you wanna go tonight?  I mean, are you working?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No, I'm off tonight.  I would lov-like, to go tonight, I can pick you up, I can pick you up here at about what time?  What time?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Eight o'clock?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: What about ten o'clock, is that too late?  I don't get off and then --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Oh sure yes, that's fine, late dinners are good.  Should I get dressed up or -- ?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No, no, just casual maybe, maybe I thought -- there's a spot I like to go, it's real nice that overlooks a golf course and the course is lit up at night --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Billingsley's?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Yeah, You know it? You know Billingsley's?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: It's my favorite place --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Oh, see?  This is great.  Ten o'clock.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Great, bye.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Did you ever go out with someone and just....lie....question after question, maybe you're trying to make yourself look cool or better than you are or whatever, or smarter or cooler and you just -- not really lie, but maybe you just don't say everything --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Well, that's a natural thing, two people go out on a date, something.  They want to impress people, the other person...or they're scared maybe what they say will make the other person not like them --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: So you've done it --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Well I don't go out very much.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I've never found someone really that I think I would like to go out with.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: And I bet you say that to all the girls --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You wanna make a deal with me?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: ok.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What I just said...y'know, people afraid to say things....no guts to say the things that they...that are real or something...

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: ...yeah...

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: To not do that.  To not do that that we've maybe done -- before --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Let's make a deal.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Ok.  I'll tell you everything and you tell me everything and maybe we can get through all the piss and shit and lies that kill other people....

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Wow....huh..."...piss and shit..."

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You really use strong language.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- no, no, it's fine. Fine.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I didn't mean...it's seems vulgar or something, I know --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: It's fine.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: ...nothing.  I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: No, I'm sorry.  I'm saying I'm sorry. I talk like a jerk sometimes --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- well I'm a real...y'know, straight when it comes to that...curse words I just don't use much --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm gonna run to the bathroom for a minute...maybe just --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: ok.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: ok.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Well.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: That felt good to do...to do what I wanted to do.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Can I tell you something?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Yeah, of course.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I'm really nervous that you're gonna hate me soon.  That you're gonna find stuff out about me and you're gonna hate me --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- no, like what, what do you mean?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You're a police officer.  You have so much, so many good things and you seem so together...so all straight and put together without problems.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I lost my gun.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I lost my gun after I left you today and I'm the laughing stock of a lot of people.  I wanted to tell you that. I wanted you to know...and it's on my mind and it makes me look like a fool and I feel like a fool and you asked that we should say things, that we should say what we're thinknig and not lie about things and I'll tell you that, this: that I lost my gun and I'm not a good cop...and I'm looked down at...and I know that....and I'm scared that once you find that out you might not like me.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Oh my god, Jim. Jim, that was so --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I'm sorry --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: That was so great what you just said.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I haven't been on a date since I was married and that was three years ago....and Claudia...whatever you wanna tell me, whatever you think might scare me, won't...and I will listen...I will be a good listener to you if that's what you want...and you know, you know...I won't judge you.... I can do that sometimes, I know, but I won't...I can...listen to you and you shouldn't be scared of scaring me off or anything that you might think I'll think or on and on and just say it and I'll listen to you....

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You don't how fuckin' stupid I am.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: It's ok.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: You don't know how crazy I am.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: It's ok.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: I've got troubles.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I'll take everything at face value. I'll be a good listener to you.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Ohhhh I started this, didn't I, didn't I, didn't I, fuck.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Say what you want and you'll see --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Wanna kiss me, Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Yes I do.

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: ....now that I've met you.... Would you object to never seeing me again?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Just say no.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I won't say, no, wait, Claudia --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: Let me go, leave me, let me go, it's ok, please.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: please, what is it, please --

turns.speaker: CLAUDIA
turns.text: just let me walk out, ok?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- you the resident here?

turns.speaker: CLAUIDA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You alone in there?

turns.speaker: CLAUIDA
turns.text: No, what's wrong?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You mind if I come in, check things?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You live alone?

turns.speaker: CLAUIDA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: CLAUIDA
turns.text: Claudia.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Claudia What?

turns.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
turns.text: Hello.  You're back again, huh?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: yeah, yes, hi, hello.

turns.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
turns.text: -- can I get you?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Diet Coke.

turns.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
turns.text: Diet Coke.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I want a shot of tequila too.

turns.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
turns.text: -- what kind?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I'm fine. Yes. I'm fine.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Ready to go,go,go?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Where's Richard and Julia?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: They're here, they're fine. In the dressing room.  See you later --

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Where's the news department at this studio?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: It's upstairs.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Have you ever been there?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Sure, why?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I'm wondering about the weather department. I'm wonderin' wether or not the weather people use outside meteorlogical services or if they have in-house instruments?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I can check on that for you, maybe we can take a tour --

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Ok.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: C'mon guys, settle down --

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Cynthia?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: How much time do we have?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Not enough, what do you want?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I should maybe go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Can you hold it?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Just hold it, you'll be fine.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I have to go to the bathroom, Cynthia.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Stanley, you can't go to the bathroom now.  You have exactly one minute before we're back on the air, this is NOT the time to go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I'm, I need to go, I'm gonna --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What happend, what's going on?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: NOTHING. NOTHING HAPPEND. GO AWAY.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Don't tell me to go away, Stanley. I am the Co-ordinator in this show and you will answer the questions that I ask, you understand?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What do you mean, "like what?" -- you could get endorsments and shit --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: -- Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Bite it, Cynthia.  You could get free things from people that want you to endorse their products.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Let's go, c'mon, get up --

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Did we win or lose, I mean --?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I don't know, Richard, they need to talk it over --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Richard, shut it and keep it down.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: If he hadn't pissed his pants, we woulda won.  We fucking had this game.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: DADDY! DAD! DAD WHAT THE HELL IS GOIN' ON?

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: Stay quiet...stay quiet, son --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: LET'S GO, LET'S GO, LET'S GET HIS MONEY AND GO -- DID YOU GET HIS MONEY? DID YOU GET IT?  DID YOU GET HIS MONEY, DAD?

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: No, Son...be quiet...be quiet now...

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: C'mon, Dad.  We gotta just GET HIS MONEY AND GO, LET'S GO. Let's get the money --

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: We're not gonna do that now.  We're not gonna do that now and that's over.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: BULLSHIT. BULLSHIT, DAD WE NEED TO GET HIS MONEY AND GO.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: GIVE US YOUR MONEY MAN.

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: Son, don't --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: BULLSHIT, BULLSHIT DAD WE GOTTA GET HIS MONEY --

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: -- no.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: GIVE US YOUR MONEY.

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: Put the gun down, please, boy.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: GIVE US YOUR MONEY, KID.

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: Son, please, now....

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: DAD --

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: Please, boy, put it down and it's ok.

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: It's ok --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: We gotta get his money so we can get outta here -- we gotta --

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: That idea is over now. We're not gonna do that now.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: DADDY, FUCK, DADDY, DON'T GET MAD AT ME. DON'T GET MAD AT ME --  JUST GIMME YOUR MONEY.

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: I'm not mad, son, I will not be mad at you and it's ok and please put it down and I won't be mad and I won't --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: DAD.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I - just - thought - that - I - didn't want - I - didn't - I - didn't -

turns.speaker: WORM
turns.text: It's ok, boy.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: How much you pay me for my help?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I think it's more complicated than that little man.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Put me on the payroll, find out, find out wassup --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You don't just sign up to be a police officer -- it's about three years of training -- ok?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I'm trained, I'm ready to go, you wanna buy some candy to help underprivelaged youth in the --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Sorry, little man.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: You wanna take my statement, I'll perform for you, gotta get paid though, gotta get PAID.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Why the hell aren't you in school?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: No school today.  My teacher got sick.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: They don't have substitute teachers where you go to school?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Nope.  So what'd they find out in there?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: That's confidential information, little man.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Tell me what you know, I'll tell you what I know --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: No Can Do.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Leave this one to the detectives, they ain't gonna solve shit, I can help you, make you the man with a plan, give you the gift that I flow -- think fast -- you wanna know who killed that guy?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Ok. Listen. You: c'mere.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: You wanna disrespect an officer of the law?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I can help you solve the case, I can tell you who did it.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Are you a joker? huh? Tellin' jokes?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I'm a rapper.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Oh, you're a rapper, huh?  You got a record contract?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Not yet -- "give you the clue for the bust if you show me some trust --"

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Have you ever been to Juvenille Hall?

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I ain't fuckin with you --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Hey. Watch the mouth. Watch it.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: C'mon, man, just watch me, watch and listen --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Go. Hurry up. Let's go.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Presence - with a double ass meaning gifts I bestow, with my riff, and my flow but you don't hear me though think fast, catch me, yo cause I throw what I know with a Resonance - fo'yo'trouble-ass fiend in weenin yo-self off the back of the shelf Jackass crackas, bodystackas dicktootin niggas, masturbatin' yo trigga butcha y'all just fake-ass niggas --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- watch the mouth, homeboy, I don't need to hear that word --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: -- livin' to get older with a chip on your shoulder 'cept you think you got a grip, cauze you hip gotta holster? Ain't no confessor, so busta, you best just Shut The fuck up, try to listen and learn --

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Alright, alright, cut it, coolio. That's enough with the mouth and the language.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: I'm almost done.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Finish it up without the lip.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Check that ego - come off it - I'm the profit - the proffesor Ima teach you 'bout The Worm, who eventually turned to catch wreck with the neck of a long time oppressor And he's runnin from the devil, but the debt is always gaining And if he's worth being hurt, he's worth bringin' pain in - When the sunshine don't work, the Good Lord bring the rain in.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Now that shit will help you SOLVE the case.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: Whatever that meant, I'm sure it's real helpful Ice-T.

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: Did you listen to me?

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: I was listening --

turns.speaker: DIXON
turns.text: -- I told you who did it and you're not listening to me.

turns.speaker: JIM KURRING
turns.text: -- and I'm through playin' games.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Doc it's Janet.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I have to talk to Frank, is he nearby?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: He's doing the interview with the lady --

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I need you to interupt him, I need to get him on the phone with me right away --

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: What happend?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Doc, go get Frank and put him on the phone.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: I'm walking towards the elevator's, Janet.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Fine.  Phil, you still there?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: What happend?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Doc, just - don't, how close are you?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: I'm about to get off the elevator --

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Phil, hang in just one more minute ok?  I'm gonna put you on hold -- Doc you still there?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Yeah, I'm here, I'm off the elevator, walking down the hall, now --

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You look like you've got money in your pocket.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Maybe I'm just happy to see my friend, Brad there.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Just throw some money around. Money, money, money.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: This sounds threatening.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Do you have love in your heart?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: I have love all over.  I even have love for you, friend.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Is it real love?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: -- the kind of love that makes you feel that intagible joy.  Pit of your stomach. Like a bucket of acid and nerves running around and making you hurt and happy and all over you're head over heels....?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Well you lost me with the last couple of cocktail words spoken, m'boy, but I believe it's that sort of love. Sounds nice to me.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I have love.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: A very chatty-kind, you do, indeed, it seems.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No.  I mean, I'm telling you: I'm telling you that I have love.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: And I'm listening avidly, fellow.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: My name is Donnie Smith and I have lot's of love to give.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: ....do you know who I am?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: You're a friend of the family I presume?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What?  What does that mean?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Nothing special, just a spoke in the wheel.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You talk in rhymes and riddles and ra...rub-adub --- but that doesn't mean anything to me, see....see...see I used to be smart....I'm Quiz Kid Donnie Smith. I'm Quiz Kid Donnie Smith from the tv --

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Might of been before my time.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: But you're alright now, so what's the what?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I used to be smart but now I'm just stupid.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Brad, dear?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Who was it that said: "A man of genius has seldom been ruined but by himself."

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: -- Samuel Johnson.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: It was the lovely Samuel Johnson who also spoke of a fella "Who was not only dull but a cause of dullness in others."

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: "The" cause of dullness in others --

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Picky, picky.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: -- and lemme tell you this: Samuel Johnson never had his life shit on and taken from him and his money stolen -- who took his life and his money?  His parents? His mommy and daddy?  Make him live this life like this -- "A man of genius" gets shit on as a child and that scars and it hurts and have you ever been hit by lighting? It hurts and it doesn't happen to everyone, it's an electrical charge that finds it's way across the universe and lands in your body and your head -- and as for "ruined but by himself," not if his parents take his friggin' life and his money and tell you to do this and do that and if you don't? well, what --

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Things go round 'n round, don't they?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes they do, they do, but I'll make my dreams come true, you see?  I will.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: This sounds Sad as a Weeping Willow.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I used to be smart but now I'm just stupid.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Shall we drink to that?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: "If a brick weighs one pound plus one half brick -- how much does the brick weigh?" "Well if subtracting the half of brick from the whole brick you got one half of brick, equals one pound so therefore the brick equals two pounds --" "A little more than kin and less than kind," is Hamlet to Claudius. "The sins of the father laid upon the children," is Merchant of Venice but borrowed from Exodus 20:5 and "win her with gifts if she respects not words," is Two Gentleman from Verona. Where? Who? How and Why, Kids?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: "Why don't you shut the fuck up," is me to you, Chapter Right Here, Verse Right Now.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I confuse melancholy and depression sometimes....

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Mmm.Hmm.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You see?

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Why don't you run along now friend, your dessert is getting cold.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm sick.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: Stay that way.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm sick and I'm in love.

turns.speaker: THURSTON
turns.text: You seem the sort of person who confuses the two.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
